awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Improved Maternal Health with Predictive Patient Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve clinical outcomes associated with preeclampsia, a potentially life-threatening condition of pregnancy occurring in the second trimester through the postpartum period. It annually affects 1 in 20 births, or 150,000 women in the U.S.A., with disadvantaged women experiencing a 2-3x increase in mortality. In the US preeclampia triples the cost of care for pregnant women, costing an estimated $2+ B per year; globally it costs 70,000 lives annually. Currently there is no way of predicting the onset of this condition.  This project proposes software to predict onset to improve clinical outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will research and develop a predictive model with 80%+ accuracy using machine learning to detect preeclampsia in the earliest stages by gathering patient-provided clinical data to inform a novel algorithm. It can be used from earliest detection through the postpartum recovery period and can provide models and alerts to both clinicians and patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Preeclampsia affects 1 in 20 births, or 150,000 women in the U.S.A. each year.  Not only does Preeclampsia cost 70,000 lives globally each year, it is also an expensive burden for the health system: it costs nearly three times more to treat a patient with preeclampsia than one without this complication.  Preeclampsia costs the US healthcare system $2.18 billion per year. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I Project conducted research to develop a predictive model using machine learning to detect preeclampsia as the condition is developing in a patient.  The technology gathers health information from patients via a proprietary phone app that the team developed for this project. Utilizing this data, the team developed a predictive model using multiple types of algorithms that predict and then alert patients when their symptoms are beginning to shows signs of preeclampsia. 

The technology is unique because it is a data-driven, predictive method for monitoring a patient from positive pregnancy test through the postpartum recovery period. Empowering patients and ensuring providers have better quality diagnostic information, this innovation has the power to elevate the standard of care for women?s health, reduce health disparities, and save lives.

In terms of societal impacts, the team imagines that this predictive model can become accepted and expected as part of the standard of care by nurse practitioners, OBGYNs and midwives for all pregnant patients in the country.  The technology developed in this SBIR grant, when deployed at scale, can be a factor to reducing maternal mortality in the United States, improving obstetric patient outcomes, reducing the cost of obstetric care, and helping to reduce health disparities for African-American and Indigenous obstetric patients, who currently die at 2-3 times the rate of other women. 


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Courtney Williams
